input_text:
[Indication]
PAP, Right side.
[Anesthesia]
GA, DLT.
[Description]
Right lung lavage. 36L In / 30L Out. Cleared secretions.
[Complication]
Transient hypoxia.
[Plan]
Extubate, ICU.
anchor_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (right lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: [REDACTED], 37-year-old female with autoimmune PAP status post left lung lavage 2 weeks ago.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen ET tube.
Procedure details: Right lung lavaged with warm saline aliquots of 800 to 1000 mL. Total instilled volume 36 L with 30 L clear return by the end of lavage. Effluent initially milky, becoming progressively clear.
Complications: Brief desaturation to low 80s during large aliquot, improved with temporary pause and recruitment maneuvers.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to ICU on high-flow nasal cannula for monitoring.
ideal_output_candidate:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis of the right lung.

CONSENT
Informed consent for bronchoscopy and whole lung lavage was obtained preoperatively.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

PROCEDURE
Right whole lung lavage (right lung).

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with a double-lumen endotracheal tube was administered.

MONITORING
Standard intraoperative monitors were used throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS
Transient hypoxia occurred intraoperatively.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
The patient was placed under general anesthesia with a double-lumen endotracheal tube for lung isolation. The right lung was lavaged using warmed saline. A total of approximately 36 liters of saline was instilled and approximately 30 liters were returned. Secretions were noted to clear over the course of the lavage.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
Right whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis was completed with approximately 36 L instilled and 30 L returned. Secretions were cleared. The procedure was complicated by transient intraoperative hypoxia. The plan was to extubate and proceed to the intensive care unit for postoperative monitoring and care.

judge_reasons: Matches source: right whole lung lavage for PAP under GA with double-lumen tube, 36 L in / 30 L out, secretions cleared, transient hypoxia, plan for extubation and ICU.
Does not introduce unsupported additional procedures; bronchoscopy is mentioned only in consent and not documented as performed.
Minor completeness gaps vs anchor: lacks details such as aliquot size, effluent description (milky to clear), specific hypoxia severity/management, and ICU respiratory support (e.g., HFNC).

attempts.report_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) affecting the right lung.

CONSENT
Informed consent for right lung lavage was obtained from the patient prior to the procedure.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

PROCEDURE
Right whole lung lavage (right lung).

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube.

MONITORING
Standard intraoperative monitoring was utilized throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS
Transient hypoxia occurred intraoperatively.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
The patient was placed under general anesthesia and intubated with a double-lumen endotracheal tube for lung isolation. The right lung was lavaged with sequential aliquots of warmed saline. A total of approximately 36 liters of fluid was instilled and approximately 30 liters of fluid was returned. Secretions were cleared during the course of the lavage. Transient hypoxia was noted during the procedure.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
1. Right whole lung lavage was performed for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis with instilled volume approximately 36 L and returned volume approximately 30 L. Secretions were cleared.
2. Transient intraoperative hypoxia occurred.
3. The patient was extubated post-procedure and transferred to the intensive care unit for continued monitoring and postoperative care per plan.
